papers_v1.title: Classification of EEG with Recurrent Neural Networks
papers_v1.description: They tried to classify whether someone is viewing a 2D or 3D image (DP3). With emphasis on Neural Networks Classificators, particulary Recurrent Neural Networks.

extra_information.title: Conclusions
extra_information.content: Is not easy use RNN and they says is necessary improve de complexity of their model of RNN. But for this case where the EEG is by nature sequences of vectors, as words are, the relationship from one element in the sequence to the next must be different. is better to use a simple feedfordward nets.

papers_v1.title: Deep Convolutional Neural Networks for Mental Load Classification based on EEG Data
papers_v1.description: They used Deep Convolutional Neural Networks for understand their effectiveness in decoding electroencephalography (EEG) signals for mental load related to memory process, with a special emphasys to evaluate many configurations for DCNN.

extra_information.title: Extra information about the method
extra_information.content: They had EEG data of 21 channels (7-frame data and each frame is composed of theta, alpha, and beta maps). Their used 6 differents models of CNN and 5 another models to compare. Their data for train and test was categorize and each EEG data represent individual mental load of different capacities during working memory tasks.

papers_v1.title: Generative Adversarial Networks Conditioned by Brain Signals
papers_v1.description: This paper try to use a modern GAN algorithm for find a relation between eeg signals and image generated from there **  (Encoder from EEG signals to discriminate between visual object categories)  **. Virtually they tried to 'read the mind'.

extra_information.title: How it did work?
extra_information.content: Six subjects partecipated in the experiment and were shown images of objects while EEG data was recorded. **  The subjects were shown 50 images from 40 different object classes4 for a total of 2,000 images per subject.  ** Each image class was presented in bursts of 25 seconds (0.5 second per image) followed by a 10 seconds pause where a black image was shown.

papers_v1.title: Evaluating Spiking Neural Models in the Classification of Motor Imagery EEG Signals using Short Calibration Sessions.
papers_v1.description: This paper talk about the use of the ** Spiking Neural Model ** for improve the time of classification for a common mental task: ** Motor Imagery **. For this goal they made a short calibration session and feature extraction before of classification stage.

extra_information.title: Conclusions
extra_information.content: ** SNM have a advantage for classify motor imagery movements **. In few cases, the RBF and the FNN achieved a better accuracy than the SNM, however, those models in average require more than 30 neurons to obtain that results, ** whereas the SNM only one neuron **.

papers_v1.title: Motor imagery classification for Brain-Computer Interfaces through a chaotic neural network
papers_v1.description: In this paper the authors try to ** improve the motor imagenery classification, specially control states **, using an online brain-computer interfaces (BCI) using ** K-sets are chaotic neural networks based on the olfactory bulb function **. They choosed this method because CHNN are good for work with noisy signals.

extra_information.title: Conclusions
extra_information.content: In this paper, a biologically motivated neural network, the KIII network, has been applied for motor imagery classification in EEG signals. The experimental results indicate that the KIII can improve the quality of classification, reducing the mean-squared error. We employed 7 public datasets from the BCI Competition IV for training and testing the KIII model. Comparisons between KIII with other algorithms (RBF, MLP, LDA and KNN) show that the K-model achieves better results in this domain. There is need for future studies to explore improvements of the proposed KIII-based method. Additional motor imagery datasets could also be explored.

papers_v2.title: EEG-based Motor Imagery Classification using Wavelet Coefficients and Ensemble Classifiers
papers_v2.description: They used a discrete wavelet transform for extract features and presenting them into classifiers, this method (Wavelet transform) has better accuracy than raw EEG data. Then suggest use a frequency transformation to try to find features and decompose the EEG signal.

papers_v2.title: Comparison of signal decomposition methods in classification of EEG signals for motor-imagery BCI system
papers_v2.description: Wavelet Packet Decomposition was superior to other signal decomposition methods. Also talk about the importance of the higher frequency into signal adquisition to improve classification in BCI systems

papers_v2.title: Mu rhythm (de)synchronization and EEG single-trial classification of different motor imagery tasks
papers_v2.description: In this paper they tried to find a desynchronized mu rhythm. This implies that such EEG phenomena may be utilized in a multi-class brain – computer interface (BCI) operated simply by motor imagery.

extra_information.title: Conclusions
extra_information.content: During performance of different motor imagery tasks, there exists not only a great intersubject variability but also a considerable intrasubject variability concerning the reactivity of upper mu components. Different types of band power changes (enhancement vs. suppression) during different imagery tasks are a prerequisite for an optimal distinctiveness between different motor imagery tasks when single trials are analyzed. We should emphasize that the ERD/ERS changes reported here were elicited by imagining movements. This implies that such EEG phenomena may be utilized in a brain – computer interface operated simply by motor imagery. Since a number of psychophysiological variables related to perceptual and memory processes and task complexity result in a desynchronization of alpha band rhythms (Klimesch, 1999), it is very difficult to discriminate between more than two mental states when only imagery-induced ERD patterns are available.

papers_v2.title: EEG-based motor imagery classification using neuro-fuzzy prediction and wavelet fractal features
papers_v2.description: In this paper, a feature extraction method through the time-series prediction based on the ANFIS time-series prediction together with multiresolution fractal feature vectors (MFFVs) is applied for feature extraction in motor imagery (MI) classification.

papers_v2.title: Classification of mental task from EEG data using neural networks based on particle swarm optimization.
papers_v2.description: This paper try to use a modern GAN algorithm for find a relation between eeg signals and image generated from there (Encoder from EEG signals to discriminate between visual object categories). Virtually they tried to 'read the mind'.

extra_information.title: Particle Swarm Information
extra_information.content: This paper try to use a modern GAN algorithm for find a relation between eeg signals and image generated from there (Encoder from EEG signals to discriminate between visual object categories).

papers_v3.description: This paper try to use a modern GAN algorithm for find a relation between eeg signals and image generated from there (Encoder from EEG signals to discriminate between visual object categories). Virtually they tried to 'read the mind'.

papers_v3.title: Filter bank common spatial pattern algorithm on BCI competition IV Datasets 2a and 2b
papers_v3.description: In this paper, the Filter Bank Common Spatial Pattern (FBCSP) algorithm is presented to enhance the performance of the CSP algorithm by performing autonomous selection of discriminative subject-specific frequency range for band-pass filtering of the EEG measurements.

extra_information.title: More about the dataset 2A
extra_information.content: BCI Competition IV (Tangermann et al., 2012) Dataset 2a comprised 4 classes of motor imagery EEG measurements from 9 subjects, namely, left hand, right hand, feet, and tongue. Two sessions, one for training and the other for evaluation, were recorded from each subject. Each session comprised 288 trials of data recorded with 22 EEG channels and 3 monopolar electrooculogram (EOG) channels (with left mastoid serving as reference). The performance of the FBCSP algorithm on the 4-class motor imagery data was evaluated by employing the 3 approaches of multi-class extension (DC, PW, and OVR) to FBCSP using the MIBIF feature selection algorithm.

papers_v3.title: EEG-based Continuous Control of a Game using a 3 Channel Motor Imagery BCI
papers_v3.description: In this paper, the authors used a 3 channels BCI and Dataset IV 2a from BCI competitions. With that, they tried to train a subject to play a 2D game. For their classificator they used and neural-time-seriesprediction-preprocessing (NTSPP).

extra_information.title: Is it useful?
extra_information.content:
A BCI which can be adapted quickly and easily to each individual with the capacity to provide accurate, stable and low latency feedback has been developed. The online performance of the new game suggests that the game can be used as new training paradigm and encourage subjects to maximize effort and help enhance performance.

![table_results](https://k62.kn3.net/5/E/3/A/3/A/F27.png)

papers_v3.title: Multi-class Filter Bank Common Spatial Pattern for Four-Class Motor Imagery BCI
papers_v3.description: This paper investigates the classification of multiclass motor imagery for electroencephalogram (EEG)-based Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) using the Filter Bank Common Spatial Pattern (FBCSP) algorithm

extra_information.title: Interesting Results
extra_information.content:
![resultstable](https://k62.kn3.net/0/A/B/C/2/E/206.png)

This paper investigated the performance of 3 approaches proposed for the multi-class extension to the Filter Bank Common Spatial Pattern (FBCSP) algorithm. These 3 approaches were evaluated on the 4-class motor imagery data of BCI Competition IV dataset IIa. The experimental results showed no significant difference between the 3 proposed approaches.

papers_v3.title: A polynomial fitting and k-NN based approach for improving classification of motor imagery BCI data
papers_v3.description: In this study, they present a method to improve the classification of BCI data. In the training procedure, the method utilizes a small portion of the complete training data. Feature vector information is extracted from only one channel. It is a twodimensional vector with a low computational load, whose entities are computed from the coefficients of the second order polynomial fitted to the signals of this channel.
